choices.text: Positive skin test for inhaled allergens

questions.text: A woman develops wheezing after taking aspirin for a headache. Which statement is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Associated with ethmoid polyps

 

  • Aspirin-induced asthma (Aspirin-Exacerbated Respiratory Disease, AERD/Samter’s triad) is classically associated with asthma, nasal polyps (especially ethmoid), and aspirin sensitivity.
  • This is not a type of extrinsic (allergic) asthma. Skin tests for inhaled allergens are typically negative, and serum IgE levels are not consistently elevated.
  • Ethmoid (and other nasal) polyps are a distinguishing feature of AERD and help separate it from other asthma subtypes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type of extrinsic asthma:

 

  • This is incorrect because AERD is not a type of extrinsic (allergic) asthma.
  • Extrinsic asthma is IgE-mediated and triggered by allergens.
  • AERD is a non-IgE-mediated, non-allergic asthma caused by abnormal metabolism of arachidonic acid leading to leukotriene overproduction after NSAID exposure.
  • This means it does not involve typical allergic sensitization pathways.

 

Option B. Raised serum IgE levels:

 

  • Typically, serum IgE is not elevated in AERD because the disease is not an allergic IgE-mediated reaction.
  • However, some studies have shown that a subset of AERD patients may have elevated total IgE without classic atopy, but this is not a defining feature of the disease.
  • The predominant mechanism relates to dysregulated mast cell activation and leukotriene production rather than IgE antibodies.

 

Option D. Positive skin test for inhaled allergens:

 

  • Skin tests for inhaled allergens are usually negative in AERD patients.
  • This is because AERD is not triggered by common environmental allergens but by cyclooxygenase inhibition from aspirin/NSAIDs.
  • Unlike extrinsic asthma, AERD’s pathophysiology involves leukotriene-mediated inflammation rather than allergen-specific IgE responses.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is admitted to the hospital due to cough, shortness of breath, and chest discomfort. He has a known history of coronary artery disease and underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 3 years ago. As a result of drug therapy, the left ventricular pressure-volume loop changes from a solid to a dashed line, as shown below. Which of the following parameters is most likely increased as a result of this change?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Stroke volume

choices.text: ATP binding site is located intracellularly
K⁺ binding site is on the extracellular side
Ouabain binds to the cytoplasmic domain

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase structure, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ouabain binds to the cytoplasmic domain

 

Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase is a transmembrane pump that maintains ionic gradients across the plasma membrane. The ATP binding site and phosphorylation site are located intracellularly, while K⁺ binding occurs extracellularly. Ouabain, a cardiac glycoside, inhibits the pump by binding to the extracellular domain, not the cytoplasmic side.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. ATP binding site is located intracellularly: True, fuels the pump.
 

Option B. K⁺ binding site is on the extracellular side: True, K⁺ enters from outside.
 

Option D. Phosphorylation site is intracellular: True, phosphorylation drives conformational change.

choices.text: Urea is cleared more efficiently than creatinine
Dialyzer membranes are made up of cellulose membranes
Higher risk of hemodynamic instability than peritoneal dialysis

questions.text: Which of the following about hemodialysis is incorrect?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Dialyzer membranes are made up of cellulose membranes

questions.text: A 56 year old asthmatic patient presents with severe headache and vomiting. BP is 220/130 mmHg, and fundus shows papilledema. What is the mechanism of action of the drug of choice?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Calcium channel blockade

choices.text: Decreased ejection fraction, increased cavity size, increased cardiac output
Increased ejection fraction, decreased cavity size, increased cardiac output
Increased ejection fraction, decreased cavity size, unchanged cardiac output
Unchanged ejection fraction, increased cavity size, increased cardiac output

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, a former elite swimmer, presents for a preconception checkup. She feels well and reports no symptoms. Vital signs are normal. Compared to a sedentary individual of the same age and sex, which cardiac changes are most likely?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Unchanged ejection fraction, increased cavity size, increased cardiac output

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with diabetes undergoes stress testing. He walks for 7 minutes without chest pain. Peak heart rate is 132/min, BP increases from 95 to 112 mmHg. Which of the following parameters was most likely decreased during peak stress?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Total systemic vascular resistance

 

During exercise, cardiac output increases due to ↑HR and ↑stroke volume. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure may rise slightly but does not decrease. Systolic BP rises, not falls. To accommodate increased flow, systemic vascular resistance decreases due to vasodilation in exercising muscles.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Cardiac output: Increases during exercise.
 

Option B. Left ventricular end-diastolic pressure: Usually stable or mildly ↑, not decreased.


Option C. Systemic systolic blood pressure: Rises, not reduced.

choices.text: Expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has difficulty walking. Exam shows pes cavus, scoliosis, and a systolic murmur at left sternal border. Which is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Association with chromosome 19

choices.text: Low renin, low aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium
Low renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium

questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the OPD due to increasing headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Medical history is significant for a transient ischemic attack that led to a right carotid endarterectomy 5 years ago. Blood pressure is 220/120 mmHg and pulse is 70/min. Bilateral abdominal bruits are present. Blood testing in this patient would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. B) High renin, high aldosterone, high angiotensin II, low potassium

Labs reveal: BUN 14 mg/dL, Creatinine 1.4 mg/dL. Which of the following mechanisms most likely underlies his renal condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) IgG immune complexes

questions.solution: Ans. A) A

questions.text: A 34-year-old man is stranded without water for 36 hours. His urine osmolality is 1100 mOsm/L. Vasopressin plays a major role in concentrating urine. Which part of the nephron responds to vasopressin by absorbing solutes crucial for medullary hypertonicity?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Medullary collecting duct

choices.text: Passive tension increases with muscle stretch
Active tension is highest at optimal length
Total tension equals sum of passive and active tension
Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length

questions.text: All are correct statements about muscle tension curves, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length

 

Passive tension develops only when a muscle is stretched beyond its resting length, due to elastic elements (like titin). At resting length, passive tension is minimal or absent. Active tension is maximal at the muscle’s optimal length, and total tension is the sum of both active and passive components.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Passive tension increases with muscle stretch: True, rises exponentially after resting length.
 

Option B. Active tension is highest at optimal length: True, due to maximum actin-myosin overlap.
 

Option C. Total tension equals sum of passive and active tension: True, reflects combined forces.

choices.text: Little dependence on extracellular calcium influx

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with hypertension is prescribed verapamil. Which skeletal muscle feature explains its resistance to this medication?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Little dependence on extracellular calcium influx

choices.text: BRCA1 is located on the long arm of chromosome 17
BRCA2 carcinomas are Luminal A type
BRCA2 mutation is associated with male breast carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the BRCA genes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA1 mutation causes well-differentiated cancer

 

This statement is incorrect. BRCA1-associated breast cancers are typically high-grade, poorly differentiated tumors. They are usually triple-negative (ER–, PR–, HER2–) and show aggressive clinical behavior. They are not well-differentiated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. BRCA1 is located on the long arm of chromosome 17: Correct. The BRCA1 gene is mapped to chromosome 17q21 and is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair.

 

Option C. BRCA2 carcinomas are Luminal A type: Correct. BRCA2-associated breast cancers are more likely to be ER-positive and fall under the Luminal A molecular subtype, which has a better prognosis compared to BRCA1 tumors.

 

Option D. BRCA2 mutation is associated with male breast carcinoma: Correct. Male breast cancer is strongly linked with BRCA2 mutations, though BRCA1 mutations can rarely be involved.

questions.text: A motorcyclist suffered a head injury 6 months back and presents with persistent memory deficits following injury. Choose the most appropriately matched option related to memory?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Medial temporal lobe - Declarative memory

questions.text: An experiment tests vascular response to norepinephrine with and without Drug A. Graph below shows Drug A curve is shifted right and down. Drug A is most similar to which agent?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Phenoxybenzamine

questions.text: What type of collagen is involved in the classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Type 5

choices.text: Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Significant coronary artery vasospasm causing flow obstruction
Ulcerated atherosclerotic plaque with partially obstructive thrombus

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the OPD due to periodic substernal chest heaviness. The pain is precipitated by fast walking and remits after 5 minutes of rest. He has a history of hypertension and smokes. BP is 140/80 mmHg, pulse 80/min. No murmurs or edema. Which of the following pathologic states is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus

choices.text: Promotes high lung volumes for efficient gas exchange

questions.text: All are advantages of the Hering-Breuer reflex, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Promotes high lung volumes for efficient gas exchange

 

The Hering-Breuer reflex primarily prevents overinflation and regulates breathing depth; it does not promote high lung volumes.

 

Hering–Breuer Reflex

 

  1. Overstretched lungs
    ↓
  2. Stretch receptors
    (Visceral pleura, bronchi, alveoli)
    ↓ Impulses through vagus nerve
  3. Respiratory center
    (Inhibits inspiratory center)
    ↓
  4. Inspiration is stopped

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Prevents overinflation during deep inspiration: True; reflex inhibits inspiration when lung stretch receptors are activated.

 

Option C. Prevents atelectasis during expiration: Reflex maintains adequate lung volume by controlling expiration.

 

Option D. Reduces unnecessary energy expenditure: Helps optimize breathing effort by modulating respiratory rhythm.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD with fatigue. He has hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes complicated by nephropathy and peripheral neuropathy. His renal function has declined steadily over the last few years. On the graph below, area "C" shows the normal relationship between serum concentrations of free calcium and parathyroid hormone. Which of the following areas most likely represents this patient's current metabolic state?
questions.solution: Ans. A) A

choices.text: Blockade of beta-1 receptors in the sinoatrial node
Blockade of calcium channels in the atrioventricular node

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with recurrent syncope. She takes lisinopril, amlodipine, and clonidine. After stopping a medication, the syncopal episodes resolve. Which of the following mechanisms most likely explains the drug's effect?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Decreasing presynaptic release of norepinephrine

choices.text: Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↑, Filtrate osmolality ↑
Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↓, Filtrate osmolality ↓
Serum sodium ↑, Tubular flow —, Filtrate osmolality ↑
Serum sodium —, Tubular flow ↓, Filtrate osmolality ↑

questions.text: A 62-year-old hypertensive man presents with headache and altered consciousness. CT shows right basal ganglia hemorrhage with midline shift. Mannitol is given IV. What is the expected acute effect of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum sodium ↓, Tubular flow ↑, Filtrate osmolality ↑

 

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic that increases tubular flow and filtrate osmolality. 
  • Water shifts from intracellular to extracellular, diluting sodium (↓ serum sodium).

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Wrong: Tubular flow increases, not decreases, with mannitol.

 

Option C. Wrong: Sodium decreases, not increases.

 

Option D. Wrong: Tubular flow increases, not decreases.

questions.text: Patients with all of the following are classified as AML with recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) t(9;22)

choices.text: ↑ PCWP, ↓ CI (cardiac index), ↑ SVR, ↓ SvO2

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes presents with fever, dysuria, and right flank pain. BP is 80/44 mmHg, pulse 134/min. Serum glucose is 72 mg/dL, urine ketones positive. Neck veins are flat. Which of the following hemodynamic parameters are most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ↓ PCWP, ↑ CI, ↓ SVR, ↑ SvO2

 

  • The patient presents with signs of septic shock: fever, hypotension, tachycardia, and signs of infection.
  • Early septic shock is characterized by:
    • Decreased systemic vascular resistance (SVR) due to vasodilation.
    • Increased cardiac index (CI) due to compensatory hyperdynamic circulation.
    • Decreased pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) as a result of peripheral vasodilation and relative hypovolemia.
    • Increased mixed venous oxygen saturation (SvO2) because tissues extract less oxygen due to abnormal oxygen utilization or shunting.

 

Other options do not fit the hemodynamic profile of early septic shock.

 

Therefore, the hemodynamic parameters are decreased PCWP, increased CI, decreased SVR, and increased SvO2.

questions.text: All of the following increase lung compliance, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inspiration

 

Inspiration decreases lung compliance temporarily because the lung tissue is stretched; lung compliance is measured during passive expiration.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pulmonary emphysema: Destroys elastic tissue causing increased compliance.

 

Option B. Normal aging: Loss of elastic recoil increases lung compliance.

 

Option D. Saline-filled lung inflation: Eliminates air-liquid interface surface tension thus increasing compliance.

questions.text: A CT scan shows a structure indicated by an arrow. This organ shares embryologic origin with which of the following tissues?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Skeletal muscle

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with poor prognosis in a patient with multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) t(11;14) 

 

t(11;14) translocation, in contrast, is generally considered to be associated with a better or standard prognosis, not poor prognosis.

 

In multiple myeloma, certain cytogenetic abnormalities and laboratory markers are associated with prognosis:

 

  • t(4;14) translocation is associated with poor prognosis.
  • High serum beta-2 microglobulin reflects tumor burden and renal function, and is linked with poor prognosis.
  • Low serum albumin is a marker of poor nutritional and general health status and correlates with poor prognosis.

choices.text: Skin thickening and induration over the shin

questions.text: A 44-year-old man has fatigue, insomnia, palpitations, and 9 kg weight loss. TSH is low, free thyroxine is high, thyroid diffusely enlarged, and TSH receptor antibodies are positive. Which of the following findings would be most specific for this patient's pathophysiologic process?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Skin thickening and induration over the shin

questions.text: Which of the following changes in the heart will not be suggestive of normal aging?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Increased left ventricular cavity size

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is found after lying on the floor for 2 days. She has dehydration, urine ketones, serum glucose 72 mg/dL, and a femoral neck fracture. Which enzyme’s increased activity is most likely contributing to both serum and urine findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hormone-sensitive lipase

 

This elderly woman was lying immobilized and fasting for 2 days, resulting in dehydration, low-normal blood glucose (72 mg/dL), and urinary ketones.
This metabolic picture indicates prolonged fasting → lipolysis → ketogenesis.

 

The key enzyme responsible for mobilizing fat stores in such fasting states is hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL).

 

Stepwise Biochemical Mechanism:

 

1. Fasting state:

 

  • Low insulin, high catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine), and cortisol.
  • These hormones activate hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) in adipose tissue.

 

2. HSL action:

 

  • Catalyzes hydrolysis of stored triglycerides → free fatty acids (FFAs) + glycerol.

 

3. Fate of products:

 

 

Hence, urinary ketones are formed due to increased fatty acid breakdown → ketogenesis.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Summary Table:

 

 

Clinical Correlation

 

  • Prolonged fasting, immobilization, or starvation → increased lipolysis → ketonuria.
  • Seen with normal or low blood glucose → hallmark of enhanced hormone-sensitive lipase activity.

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image showing deposits in the kidney. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Membranous nephropathy

 

Key points from EM:

 

  • Electron-dense deposits are seen subepithelially (between the podocyte and GBM).

 

  • This is characteristic of primary or secondary membranous nephropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Goodpasture syndrome: Anti-GBM disease; EM shows linear IgG deposits, not subepithelial electron-dense deposits.

 

Option B. Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN): EM shows subendothelial or mesangial deposits with GBM splitting (“tram-track” appearance).

 

Option D. Minimal change disease: EM shows podocyte foot process effacement but no deposits.

 

Classic clue: Subepithelial electron-dense deposits → Membranous nephropathy.

questions.text: All of the following drugs show increased absorption with food, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Azithromycin

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with headaches, fatigue, visual disturbances. He has sarcoidosis, mild hypercalcemia, and MRI shows mass in hypothalamus and pituitary stalk. Which of the following pituitary hormones is most likely elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolactin 

 

Mass lesions in the hypothalamus or pituitary stalk can disrupt dopamine inhibition, causing elevated prolactin (hyperprolactinemia) which explains the symptoms. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. ACTH: Not typically elevated unless there is an ACTH-secreting tumor. 

 

Option B. Growth hormone: Growth hormone elevation unrelated to this presentation. 

 

Option D. Thyrotropin: Elevated TSH would cause hyperthyroidism, not typically linked here.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with epigastric pain and positive occult blood test undergoes endoscopy, revealing hyperemic nodular mucosa. Biopsy shows submucosal glands producing alkaline mucus. Which part of the GI tract was biopsied?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First part of the duodenum

 

  • The submucosal glands producing alkaline mucus are Brunner’s glands, found only in the duodenum (especially the first part).
  • Their function is to secrete alkaline mucus that neutralizes gastric acid, protecting the duodenal mucosa and providing the right pH for pancreatic enzyme activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mid-jejunum: Jejunum has prominent plicae circulares but no submucosal glands.

 

Option C. Antrum of the stomach: Contains mucous cells in gastric pits, but not submucosal alkaline glands.

 

Option D. Terminal ileum: Contains Peyer’s patches (lymphoid tissue), not mucus-secreting submucosal glands.

 

Presence of Brunner’s glands = Duodenum (1st part).

questions.text: Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of the liver in chronic Hepatitis B?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Ballooning degeneration

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the OPD due to several weeks of progressive exertional dyspnea and lower extremity edema. Echocardiography shows biventricular dilation and a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. After initial stabilization, long-term use of which of the following medications will most likely improve survival in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Carvedilol

questions.text: All of the following are true for non-microsomal enzymes, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Carry out glucuronidation reactions

choices.text: Blood cell counts and mean corpuscular volume

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents for evaluation of elevated blood glucose. BMI is 31.5 kg/m². HbA1c is 8.5% and fasting plasma glucose is 146 mg/dL. She is planned to start metformin. Which of the following laboratory tests should be obtained prior to starting this medication?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Serum creatinine level

choices.text: ↑ 24-hour urinary cortisol, ↓ ACTH, Normal DHEAS
Normal 24-hour urinary cortisol, Normal ACTH, ↑ DHEAS

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman reports irregular menstruation and 4.5 kg weight gain over 6 months. BP is 152/86 mmHg, BMI is 31 kg/m². Physical exam shows abdominal and supraclavicular fat accumulation, hyperpigmentation in skin creases, and wide abdominal striae. Which of the following sets of laboratory findings are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) ↑ 24-hour urinary cortisol, ↑ ACTH, ↑ DHEAS

choices.text: Neutrophilic crypt abscesses in the colon
Eosinophilic infiltration in the distal colon
Hemorrhagic necrosis of the intestinal wall
Presence of heterotopic gastric mucosa in the distal ileum

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant, born at 35 weeks gestation, presents with blood-streaked, mucous-filled diarrhea after taking a standard cow's milk-based formula. Symptoms resolved upon switching the formula. If a biopsy was performed during the symptomatic period, which of the following histological findings would most likely be observed?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Eosinophilic infiltration in the distal colon

questions.text: All of the following conditions show onion skin appearance, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Marfan syndrome

questions.text: All of the following anticoagulants inhibit both Factor Xa and Factor IIa, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fondaparinux

 

This drug inhibit both Factor Xa & Factor IIa

 

Fondaparinux selectively inhibits only Factor Xa and does not inhibit Factor IIa.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unfractionated heparin: Unfractionated heparin inhibits both Factor Xa and Factor IIa (thrombin).

 

Option B. LMWH: Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) inhibits both Factor Xa and Factor IIa, although it has a stronger effect on Factor Xa.

choices.text: Ethanol competitively inhibits hepatic cytochrome P450
Ethanol impairs intestinal absorption of acetaminophen

questions.text: A 42-year-old male is brought to the ED after ingesting multiple acetaminophen tablets along with alcohol in a suspected suicide attempt. He has no chronic alcohol use history. The physician informs the family that acute ethanol ingestion may reduce acetaminophen toxicity. Which mechanism best explains this protective effect?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Ethanol competitively inhibits hepatic cytochrome P450

choices.text: Composed mainly of red cells (Red Thrombi)

questions.text: All are features of venous thrombus, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Caused by turbulent blood flow

 

Venous thrombi are caused by stasis of blood, not turbulence (which is seen in arterial thrombi).

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Common in deep leg veins: True, most venous thrombi occur in deep veins of the leg.
 

Option C. Propagate in antegrade manner: True, venous thrombi extend in the direction of blood flow.
 

Option D. Composed mainly of red cells (red thrombi): True, venous thrombi are rich in RBCs and fibrin.

choices.text: It is  produced entirely from mouse
It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting HER-2 antigen
It is a monoclonal antibody containing only human component

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Trastuzumab is true?
questions.solution: Ans. B) It is a monoclonal antibody produced by injecting HER-2 antigen

questions.text: Identify the correct pair?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) D-Nephrogenic DI

 

On the graph, curve D shows consistently low urine osmolality that does not rise with either water deprivation or desmopressin administration. This pattern is characteristic of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI), where the kidneys are unable to respond to antidiuretic hormone (ADH) even after desmopressin, resulting in persistently dilute urine.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. B – Normal: Incorrect; B responds to water deprivation and desmopressin but is not normal.

 

Option B. C - Primary polydipsia: C shows improvement with desmopressin, more typical for central DI, not primary polydipsia.

 

Option D. B - Central DI: In central DI, urine osmolality sharply rises only after desmopressin, which matches pattern C, not B.

choices.text: Intestine – Paneth cells near base of crypt
Skin – Bulge region of hair follicle

questions.text: All tissues are correctly matched to their stem cell location, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cornea – Ciliary body

choices.text: It is due to denaturation of protein
It is due to enzymatic digestion

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding necrosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) It is an active process

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD for follow-up of type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient is taking the maximum dose of metformin. Her hemoglobin HbA1c is 7.7%. Blood pressure is 134/86 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Family history is significant for osteoporosis in mother. The results of other laboratory tests are normal. After discussion, a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor is added to the patient's drug regimen. Which of the following is the most likely additional effect of the newly prescribed medication?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Decreased blood pressure

questions.text: When does the relative refractory period begin?
questions.solution: Ans. C) One-third of repolarization

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is referred for evaluation because of hematuria and haemoptysis since 2 weeks. DLCO is 120% of normal with normal lung volumes. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Microscopic polyangiitis

 

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small-vessel vasculitis causing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary capillaritis, presenting with hematuria and hemoptysis. Elevated DLCO suggests alveolar hemorrhage due to increased carbon monoxide uptake. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Pulmonary hypertension: Does not cause hematuria and usually lowers DLCO. 

 

Option B. Asthma: Causes airway obstruction, not hematuria or hemoptysis. 

 

Option C. Wegener’s granulomatosis: Also causes hematuria and hemoptysis but typically associated with granulomas and elevated c-ANCA, which differentiates it from microscopic polyangiitis.

choices.text: In combination with a short-acting β2-agonist

questions.text: What is the Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA)'s recommendation regarding the use of long-acting β2-agonists (LABA)?
questions.solution: Ans. C) With an inhaled corticosteroid

questions.text: Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CK7 negative, CK20 negative

 

Clear cell renal cell carcinoma is characteristically negative for both CK7 and CK20.

 

Other Options:


Option A. CK7 positive, CK20 positive: Incorrect, this pattern is typical for some urothelial carcinomas, not RCC.
 

Option B. CK7 negative, CK20 positive: Incorrect, CK20 positivity is not seen in RCC.
 

Option C. CK7 positive, CK20 negative: Incorrect, CK7 can be positive in papillary RCC, but not in clear cell RCC (the most common subtype).

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for COPD in a patient with dementia?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Tiotropium

choices.text: Congo red under polarizing light – Apple-green birefringence

questions.text: All of the following are correct about amyloid appearance, except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) H&E stain – Basophilic extracellular substance

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the effect of parathyroid hormone (PTH) on bone remodeling. Half of the study subjects receive intermittent PTH injections and the other half receive a continuous infusion of PTH. The results show that the effects on bone metabolism of intermittent PTH injections are different from those of continuous infusion. Which of the following is most likely to be the predominant bone effect with intermittent injections?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Stimulation of osteoblast activity

choices.text: IgG is used to diagnose fetal infection
IgA exists in secretory form as a dimer

questions.text: Which of the following statements about immunoglobulins is false?
questions.solution: Ans. A) IgG is used to diagnose fetal infection

choices.text: It does not bind to albumin

questions.text: A new aminoglycoside antibiotic is developed that is believed to be particularly effective against Pseudomonas. The volume of distribution of the drug is measured in a group of volunteers and is determined to be 4.5 L. This new drug is most likely to have which of the following properties?
questions.solution: Ans. D) It is highly charged

questions.text: Which of the following is called leukocyte common antigen?
questions.solution: Ans. B) CD45

questions.text: All of the following cause intravascular hemolysis, except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Hereditary spherocytosis

questions.text: Which color vacutainer will you pick for PT and aPTT?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Blue

questions.text: Which substance leads to relaxation in mesangial cells?
questions.solution: Ans. D) cAMP

questions.text: Upon reactivation of VZV, the virus is transported through the nerve axon to the skin. Which of the following proteins is most likely involved in the transport process leading to disease recurrence?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Kinesin

questions.text: According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, prescription drugs fall under which schedule?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Schedule H

questions.text: All of the following are correctly matched drug-induced liver pathologies, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methotrexate – Cholestatic pattern

 

Methotrexate primarily causes hepatic fibrosis and cirrhosis, not cholestatic injury.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate – Microvesicular steatosis: Valproate → Microvesicular steatosis (Reye-like).

 

Option B. Halothane – Massive necrosis: Halothane → Massive hepatic necrosis.

 

Option D. Allopurinol – Fibrin ring granulomas: Allopurinol → Fibrin ring granulomas (rare hypersensitivity).

questions.text: Two weeks after being treated for nongonococcal urethritis, a 34-year-old man develops acute conjunctivitis, right-knee pain, and vesicular lesions on his palms and soles. This syndrome is most strongly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Sacroiliitis

questions.text: Which function of growth hormone (GH) is specifically mediated via IGF-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Antilipolysis

 

The antilipolytic effect of growth hormone is indirectly mediated by IGF-1, which promotes fat storage by opposing GH’s direct lipolytic actions. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Sodium retention: Directly mediated by GH, not IGF-1. 

 

Option B. Lipolysis: A direct effect of GH, independent of IGF-1. 

 

Option C. Reduced insulin sensitivity: Also a direct effect of GH on peripheral tissues, not IGF-1.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-obesity drugs is a selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lorcaserin

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked in the following image?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Titin

questions.text: All of the following are tauopathies, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) REM behavioral disorder

 

Tauopathies are neurodegenerative diseases characterized by abnormal aggregation of hyperphosphorylated tau protein in neurons and glia. Examples include Pick’s disease, corticobasal degeneration, and progressive supranuclear palsy.


REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia, not a tauopathy. It is most often associated with α-synucleinopathies (e.g., Parkinson’s disease, Lewy body dementia, multiple system atrophy).

 

Linked to α-synucleinopathies, not a tauopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pick’s disease: A frontotemporal lobar degeneration with Pick bodies (tau inclusions).


Option B. Corticobasal degeneration: A tauopathy with asymmetric cortical atrophy and basal ganglia involvement.


Option C. Progressive supranuclear palsy: A classic tauopathy with supranuclear gaze palsy and postural instability.

questions.text: Match the neurotransmitter with its correct receptor type:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GABA-A - Ionotropic 

 

GABA-A is a ligand-gated chloride ion channel, hence ionotropic.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Glycine – G-Protein Coupled Receptor: Glycine receptor is ionotropic (Cl⁻ channel), not GPCR.
 

Option C. Nicotinic – G-Protein Coupled Receptor: Nicotinic ACh receptor is ionotropic (Na⁺/K⁺ channel).
 

Option D. GABA-B – Ionotropic: GABA-B is metabotropic (GPCR), not ionotropic.

questions.text: Among the following antimuscarinic drugs used in the treatment of overactive bladder, which one shows direct spasmolytic activity on smooth muscles?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Oxybutynin

choices.text: Leftward shift of oxygen dissociation curve

questions.text: During adaptation to high altitude, which of the following does not occur?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Leftward shift of oxygen dissociation curve

questions.text: A patient with central diabetes insipidus is prescribed intranasal desmopressin. Which of the following is not a valid reason for preferring it over intravenous vasopressin?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Greater selectivity for V1 receptor

questions.text: The serotonergic cell bodies of the analgesia pathway projecting to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord are located in which part of the brain?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nucleus raphe

 

The descending pain modulation pathway originates in the periaqueductal gray (PAG), which activates the nucleus raphe magnus (a raphe nucleus in the medulla). The raphe nuclei contain serotonergic neurons that project to the dorsal horn of the spinal cord to inhibit pain transmission.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Periaqueductal gray area: Initiates descending pain inhibition but not the main serotonergic cell body site.
 

Option B. Rostral ventromedial medulla: Includes the raphe nuclei, but serotonergic cell bodies are specifically in nucleus raphe magnus.
 

Option C. Locus ceruleus: Noradrenergic center, not serotonergic.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with CKD is scheduled for surgery. Her serum creatinine is 2.4 mg/dL and eGFR is 13. Which of the following opioids can be safely used in her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Remifentanil

 

  • Remifentanil is an ultra–short-acting synthetic opioid.
  • It is metabolized by plasma and tissue esterases, not by liver or kidney.
  • Hence, its clearance is independent of renal or hepatic function, making it the safest opioid in patients with severe CKD (eGFR 13).
  • Duration of action is very short, ideal for intraoperative analgesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine (Meperidine): Metabolized to normeperidine, a toxic metabolite that accumulates in renal failure and causes seizures. Contraindicated in CKD.

 

Option C. Alfentanil: Primarily metabolized by the liver, but partly dependent on renal clearance. Accumulation can occur in CKD, so not the safest choice.

 

Option D. Morphine: Metabolized to morphine-6-glucuronide, which is renally excreted. In CKD, it accumulates → prolonged sedation, respiratory depression, neurotoxicity.

questions.text: Which part of the vascular system has the greatest compliance?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Veins

questions.text: All are components of MELD 3.0 score, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Platelet count

 

Platelet count is not a component of the MELD 3.0 score. Thrombocytopenia is often seen in cirrhosis due to splenic sequestration and portal hypertension, but it is not included in the MELD-based prognostic scoring system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. INR: Included in MELD, as it reflects hepatic synthetic function and degree of coagulopathy, both of which worsen with advanced liver disease.

 

Option B. Female sex: MELD 3.0 adjusted for female sex, since women were found to have higher waitlist mortality compared to men at the same MELD score.

 

Option D. Creatinine: A major component of MELD, reflecting renal dysfunction, which is strongly associated with poor prognosis in cirrhotic patients.

questions.text: A patient suffering from hyperthyroidism is administered a drug that acts by inhibiting the release of thyroid hormone. Identify the drug:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Potassium iodide

questions.text: Highest mineralocorticoid activity is seen with which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Aldosterone

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

choices.text: Presence of carbonic anhydrase in luminal membrane
Lack of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in the basolateral membrane
Possession of brush border on luminal membrane

questions.text: What differentiates the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) from the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Presence of ‘tight’ tight junctions 

 

  • The distal convoluted tubule has tight tight junctions which make it less leaky than the proximal tubule, allowing precise regulation of ion and water reabsorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Presence of carbonic anhydrase in luminal membrane: Present in PCT, not unique to DCT.

 

Option B. Lack of Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase in the basolateral membrane: DCT has Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase for active sodium reabsorption.

 

Option C. Possession of brush border on luminal membrane: Brush border is characteristic of PCT, not DCT.

questions.text: A 45 year old male with erectile dysfunction was prescribed sildenafil. He develops bluish-green vision. Inhibition of which enzyme is the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phosphodiesterase 6

 

Sildenafil primarily inhibits PDE5 to treat erectile dysfunction, but cross-inhibition of PDE6 in retinal photoreceptors leads to bluish-green vision disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphodiesterase 3: Found in heart & vascular smooth muscle; inhibition affects contractility, not color vision.

 

Option B. Phosphodiesterase 5: Main target for erectile dysfunction; doesn’t cause visual side effects directly.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase 2: Found in heart and CNS; unrelated to visual perception.

choices.text: Symptoms can include diarrhea, vomiting, jaundice, and confusion
High-dose propranolol can reduce T4 to T3 conversion

questions.text: Regarding thyroid storm, which statement is false?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Mortality is 10% despite treatment

questions.text: All streptococcal antigen–host antigen–disease associations are true, except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid – Skin - Impetigo

questions.text: A woman presents with signs of hyperthyroidism. Which feature is not typically associated with her condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Reduced protein breakdown

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true of the baroreceptor reflex pathway?

 

  1. Rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) is inhibited by CVLM. 
  2. Caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) releases GABA.
  3. Nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) releases GABA.
  4. Stretch receptors are stimulated by increased blood pressure
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4

 

In the baroreceptor reflex pathway:

 

1. The rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM), which drives sympathetic outflow, is inhibited by the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) during increased blood pressure to reduce sympathetic tone.

 

2. The CVLM releases GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter that suppresses the RVLM.

 

4. Stretch receptors (baroreceptors) are stimulated by increased blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

3. The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) primarily receives afferent input from baroreceptors and is primarily excitatory, not generally releasing GABA.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Balint syndrome except:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Denial of blindness

choices.text: Innervated by a single nerve ending per fiber
Fibers are connected via many gap junctions and contract as a syncytium

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of single-unit (visceral) smooth muscle?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Fibers are connected via many gap junctions and contract as a syncytium

questions.text: Which neuropeptide has an orexigenic effect?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Neuropeptide Y

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about the recruitment of fast fatiguable motor unit?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Recruited last

questions.text: What is this nail finding detected incidentally in a young girl called?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Beau’s lines

choices.text: Get USG to rule out obstructive uropathy

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever and joint pains. He is being treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. His urine has turned darker. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 15/min. Examination shows a skin rash; examination otherwise shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows: 8 RBCs/HPF, 12 WBCs/HPF with white cell casts, eosinophiluria, and a mild degree of proteinuria. Laboratory studies show a BUN of 40 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 2.2 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Discontinue cephalexin

choices.text: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node
Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness while playing video games. He states this has occurred intermittently over the past year, but the episodes typically resolve spontaneously after a few minutes. He denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. ECG is shown below. Which of the following abnormalities is most likely present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity

 

Given the clinical presentation of a 17-year-old with sudden-onset palpitations and lightheadedness, with intermittent episodes resolving spontaneously, this suggests a supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) of atrial origin.

 

The ECG likely shows a narrow complex tachycardia consistent with an atrial tachycardia arising from an ectopic atrial pacemaker.

 

Ectopic atrial pacemaker activity matches ectopic atrial tachycardia, causing palpitations from abnormal atrial impulses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node: Accessory pathway bypassing the AV node is typical of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, causing atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), usually diagnosed with characteristic delta waves on ECG.

 

Option B. Degeneration of the atrioventricular conduction system: Degeneration of the AV conduction system causes heart block, uncommon in young patients and unlikely to cause SVT.

 

Option D. Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node: Dysfunction of the sinoatrial node results in bradycardia or pauses, not tachycardia.
